problem_statement: Find the shortest distance between two parallel lines L1: r = a + t b and L2: r = c + s b, and prove that δ = |(c - a) × b| / |b| using actual coordinate values.

step_details.explanation: Write the equations of the two given lines using the given position vectors and common direction vector.
The two lines are parallel because both have the same direction vector b = (2,-1,2). To find the shortest distance, drop a perpendicular from point A on L1 to L2.
The shortest distance between two parallel lines is the length of the perpendicular from A to L2. This perpendicular is perpendicular to b and lies in the plane containing A and C.
Now compute the cross product AC × b.
Find the magnitude of AC × b and the magnitude of b.
Apply the formula δ = |(c - a) × b| / |b| to get the shortest distance.
Thus, the shortest distance between the two given parallel lines is √13 units. This verifies the formula δ = |(c - a) × b| / |b|.
